content: The Act titled "Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007" provides information on health insurance options for small businesses. The definitions in this section of the Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007 include terms like Administration, Administrator, association, and participating small business development center. These terms are defined in relation to the Small Business Administration and small business development centers accredited under the Small Business Act. The Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007 establishes a pilot program to provide grants to small business development centers for offering neutral information on health insurance. The program defines terms like small business concern and State in relation to the Small Business Act. The Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007 establishes a pilot program to provide grants for small business development centers to offer information on health insurance options, including coverage within the small group market. The Administrator will post guidance on grant applications and types of educational materials to be created under the program. The Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007 establishes a pilot program for small business development centers to offer information on health insurance options. Centers must submit an application to receive a grant, with the Administrator selecting up to 20 centers. Selection criteria include limiting programs per state and group of states. The Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007 establishes a pilot program for small business development centers to offer information on health insurance options. The program limits the number of programs in each state and groups states into five categories. The Small Business Health Insurance Options Act of 2007 establishes a pilot program for small business development centers to offer information on health insurance options. States are grouped into categories for the program, with each group consisting of specific states. The Administrator must make selections within 6 months after the required information is posted on the website. The pilot program for small business development centers involves creating and distributing informational materials, conducting training activities, and incorporating existing resources on health insurance options. The pilot program for small business development centers includes providing neutral and objective information on health insurance options in the geographic area, including traditional employer-sponsored health insurance. The pilot program for small business development centers provides grants ranging from $150,000 to $300,000 per fiscal year, with a matching requirement for assistance. Participating centers must submit quarterly reports to Senate and House committees. The pilot program for small business development centers provides grants for health insurance options and educational materials. $5,000,000 is authorized for the first fiscal year, with an additional $5,000,000 for each of the following 3 fiscal years. The Administrator can only use appropriated funds for the program.
